messages: 932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (20:52): Anyone know if the Patent Policy implications of the WHAT WG submission has been dealt with?
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (20:55): pings anne and Hixie...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:56): 932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4: which implications specifically?
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (20:56): The proposal only mentions copyright assignment; has it been vetted for Royalty-Free Patent Licensing as well?
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (20:57): 932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4: as in patent searches?
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (20:58): No, as in with normal submissions from companies to the W3C. The WHAT WG submission is a little out of the ordinary for this.
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:00): pardon my ignorance. how are normal submissions vetted?

932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:01): IOW, do the undersigned on the proposal claim they either are not aware of any patents covering the material, or any patents are available for license on a Royalty-Free basis.
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:03): from what I gather that doesn't matter
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:03): when the spec goes to call for comments any vendors must explicitly object to any content that is under their patent control
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:03): and if they don't, it's free for use in the final spec
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:04): Apple has already said they won't do that for <canvas> etc.
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:04): (the above was gleaned from several list posts)
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:04): Hmm. Ok. So we assume it won't be a problem, but it hasn't been explicitly dealt with?
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:05): it was explicitly addressed on the list. check the earliest archives...probably in the first 50 threads
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:05): can barely keep up with the latest threads... :-)
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:06): has just been marking all unread threads as read for the past week
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:06): it's just more of the same
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:07): Yeah, too much noise to pick out the productive bits.
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:07): I just drop in on Maciej's or Ian's replies every now and then to see what's going on :)
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:07): looks accusingly in the Chairs' general direction...
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:09): checks clock to find out how long he has to decide whether to object or not...
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:15): 932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4: surely you aren't going to object on patent grounds?
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:16): If it was an actual problem I would, but mainly just to make sure it got handled.
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:16): I'm reviewing the questions up for vote against the Charter, among other things.
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:18): Trying to figure out which of my misgivings are for substantive reasons and which are just preference, subjective, etc.
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:19): bahs at John Boyer's reasoning for a "no"
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:20): it's a semantically invalid argument if we're going to be picky
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (21:21): 932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4, what issues are you concerned with?
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:22): Trying to figure that out, actually. :-)
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:22): I think at the base I'm concerned with the attitude and goals underlying, in particular, the ‚ÄúHTML5‚Äù submission.
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (21:22): I can totally understand that
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:23): But I'm as yet undecided on whether or not there is anything in there that constitutes a substantive issue.
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (21:23): I think they have made a very poor attempt at explaining why this would be a good idea
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (21:23): the arguments have been, in tone if not in substance, "shut up and let us have what we want"
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:24): Particularly since the Charter, on further review, seems to one of the things I'm concerned about (and the Charter is out of scope for the current vote).
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:24): I think good explanations have been made, but have been drowned out in confusion and misunderstandings
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (21:24): 62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e: I agree, there have been very lucid posts
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:24): Another concern for me is the navel-gazing quality of the arguments.
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (21:25): 932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4: that's been on both sides
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:25): notes that the attitude and goals have translated to results: http://ln.hixie.ch/?start=1172653243&count=1
1adba86c435b5fe0f7ea043370b1636b (21:25): b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424: which "this" are you referring to above? the current vote for editor/starting point/name?
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (21:26): 1adba86c435b5fe0f7ea043370b1636b: yes, specifically taking the WHAWG proposal

932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:27): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Yes, I'm the first to lambast the recent hostory of W3C WG's, the late HTML WG in particular, particularly on secrecy and non-responsiveness.
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:27): have you read the reasons given in the survey next to the "yes" answers?

b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (21:27): I think it's reasonable to expect people to read it before judging, but I also think that it's unreasonable to demand an immediate vote on it without giving people a chance to read it
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:27): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: However, that was not the issue I was referring to.
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:28): b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424: to be fair, it's asking whether or not the spec should be admitted for discussion -- reading it is not a prerequisite
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:28): knowing the gist is, however
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (21:28): 62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e: I don't think that's realistic... in a way, it is a fiat, because of momentum
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:29): I don't see it as fiat at all. the resulting discussions in this WG could invalidate everything in the current spec
b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9 (21:29): 932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4: it illustrates getting stuff done vs. discussing it in a committee
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:29): fiat would be mandating its inclusion in the final spec somehow
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:30): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: Sure. But the WHAT WG does not represent the needs of the sum total of the web.

b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (21:30): 62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e: but it also includes buying into Hixie as the editor, and he's very tenacious, and would strongly resist any attempts at changing it, right?
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:30): the WHAT WG represented and championed the needs of web authors and browser vendors (two of the largest groups on the web) for several years
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:31): b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424: that's a completely separate question
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:31): b8810fee2f4a71f849f3f7409546d1d9: And that realization has not been particularly prominent in their interactions with those who dissent.
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:31): and Hixie doesn't resist changes to the spec when they're presented with a strong argument and real evidence
1adba86c435b5fe0f7ea043370b1636b (21:31): b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424: I don't think it's fair to say that Hixie would resist any attempt to change the spec
62e1e89124794c1ee4b8ec5965cfb90e (21:31): he's one of the most rational people I've had the pleasure of interacting with on specs
1adba86c435b5fe0f7ea043370b1636b (21:32): b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424: he has been convinced to change things, and has said there are things he'd like to change
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (21:32): 932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4: fwiw, I have decided that on most of the substantive issues, it's most productive to go with the flow on this vote

932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:32): I would have formally objected to Hixie as Editor if the Charter hadn't explicitly said that the HTML WG should ‚Äúactively seek convergence with the WHAT WG‚Äù.
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:33): b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424: I'm, as mentioned, as yet undecided on whether any of my misgivings represent actual substantive issues.
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (21:34): fair enough

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:34): I believe any reading of the spec requires discussion beforehand - there are several obvious areas (like <font style>, WF2 repetition) where the spec says something that most WHATWG people are unhappy with and which are very likely to be changed, but you can't tell that just from reading it; so the reading and arguments against features need to be guided carefully so that they're usefully targetted

ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:35): Uh, I've forgotten why I thought that was a relevant point, except I guess that means reviewing the spec before judging it will take quite a bit of time and cooperation
b65a1668d3f56352ebf6e4735afeb424 (21:36): 932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4: let your conscience decide, but also consider what the implications of a formal objection are, and if that meets your goals
ab7faae5d7b250ea8606486575f8f79c (21:37): Oh, maybe the point was that that reading would require significant commitment too, hence the value of formally voting before starting to do that work
932b433e8e456828a538f138916e4fc4 (21:47): Ugh. Anyone else occasionally getting the raw markup instead of cooked display for the ballot page in Safari?
